body.p: This page gives a brief summary of archaeological work carried out at the site of Nimrud over the past two centuries. For more detail see and Chapters 1–3, 5–12 of .
Before excavation | The Victorian era | The early twentieth century | The Cold War era | The Saddam era | The twenty-first century

dl.dd: The Ottoman provincial governor of Mosul, Ahmed Pasha Jalili, quarries for building stone
James Silk Buckingham visits the site ("Nimrod-Tuppe") on 8 September, noting that it might contain ancient ruins
Claudius James Rich — the East India Company's Resident in Baghdad — visits the site on 4 March, noticing the remains of the ziggurat and collecting fragments of inscribed bricks from the surface
Two brief visits by members of the British expedition to chart the Euphrates, on 9 March and 3 June, each noting many fragmentary antiquities on the surface of the mound
British missionary Rev George Badger surveys the site in March and proposes its excavation to Sir Stratford Canning; another missionary, Rev James Fletcher, digs for inscribed bricks

esp:image.description: Layard's plan of the Northwest palace showing sculptures removed by 1900

esp:link.title: Large version ofLayard's plan of the Northwest palace showing sculptures removed by 1900

esp:image.esp:caption: Image 2: Layard's plan of his excavations at the Northwest Palace , marked in bright and pale blue and green to indicate which sculptures had been fully or partially removed by 1850 and 1900 respectively . (Rooms A, J, K, M, O, R, U, V, W, X, Y AA, BB did not contain figural bas-reliefs.) View large image.

dl.dd: Austen Henry Layard excavates parts of the Southwest Palace and the ceremonial areas of king Assurnasirpal II's Northwest Palace, by tunnelling along the edges of walls lined with stone bas-reliefs; his most spectacular finds include the Black Obelisk

Layard returns to Nimrud, assisted by Hormuzd Rassam and the artist Frederick Cooper, focusing especially on the ziggurrat and surrounding shrines. Solomon Malan and the Hon. Robert Clive each visit in 1850
Felix Jones maps Nimrud and its surroundings for the East India Company; Rawlinson visits to study the inscriptions that are still in situ
Rassam digs mostly at Nineveh but also at Nimrud and Sherif Khan (ancient Tarbiṣu)

William Kennett Loftus, with artist William Boutcher, dig on behalf of the British Museum and the private Assyrian Excavation Fund, at the "Southeast Palace", i.e., the Burnt Palace and Nabu's temple, and probably also at king Tiglath-pileser III's Central Palace; they find many ivories
Julius Weber, a Swiss entrepreneur, visits Nimrud to acquire reliefs
Henri-Pacifique Delaporte, the French consul at Baghdad, vists Nimrud and sends reliefs to the Louvre
George Smith excavates briefly on behalf of The Daily Telegraph and the British Museum
Rassam returns to Nimrud, commissioning photographs too

esp:link.title: Large version of Layard's plan of the Northwest palace showing sculptures removed by 1950

esp:image.esp:caption: Image 3: Layard's plan of his excavations at the Northwest Palace , marked in bright and pale blue, green and purple to indicate which sculptures had been fully or partially removed by 1850, 1900 and 1950 respectively . (Rooms A, J, K, M, O, R, U, V, W, X, Y AA, BB did not contain figural bas-reliefs.) View large image.

dl.dd: Walter Andrae, a German archaeologist excavating at Assur, visits and photographs Nimrud
The archaeologist and explorer Gertrude Bell visits Nimrud, taking photographs
British archaeologists, including Max Mallowan, visit Nimrud from Reginald Campbell Thompson's excavations at Nineveh

Max Mallowan directs large-scale excavations on the citadel for BSAI, first extending the plan of the Northwest Palace, then working on the Governor's Palace, the citadel walls and associated housing, and the Burnt Palace
Behnam Abu es-Soof directs excavation and restoration work on the Northwest Palace
Mallowan resumes excavations for BSAI, at Nabu's temple, and Ninurta's temple and its ziggurat, and begins work on Fort Shalmaneser
David Oates directs BSAI's excavations at Fort Shalmaneser, replaced by Jeffrey Orchard in 1963
Said al-Iraqi and Hazim Abd el-Hamid re-excavate and restore much of the Northwest Palace for the Iraqi Department of Antiquities, including excavation of many ivories from the Well in courtyard AJ
Janusz Meuszyński directs Polish archaeological work at the Northwest Palace and the central part of the royal citadel

esp:link.title: Large version of Layard's plan of the Northwest palace showing sculptures removed by 2000

esp:image.esp:caption: Image 4: Layard's plan of his excavations at the Northwest Palace , marked in bright and pale blue, green, purple and yellow to indicate which sculptures had been fully or partially removed by 1850, 1900, 1950 and 2000 respectively . (Rooms A, J, K, M, O, R, U, V, W, X, Y AA, BB did not contain figural bas-reliefs.) View large image.

dl.dd: Muzahim Mahmoud Hussain re-excavates and restores Nabu's temple and further areas of the Northwest Palace, for the State Board of Antiquities and Heritage (SBAH), finding the famous queens' tombs in 1988 and Well 4 in 1992
Paolo Fiorina leads Italian excavation work in Fort Shalmaneser and the nearby city walls
John Curtis directs small-scale excavations at Fort Shalmaneser for the British Museum
International projects at Nimrud are stopped in the run-up to the Gulf War
Muzahim Mahmoud Hussain re-excavates Ištar's temple for the SBAH
The BSAI and British Museum hold a large conference to re-evaluate the archaeology of Nimrud

esp:image.description: Layard's plan of the Northwest palace showing sculptures removed by 2015

esp:link.title: Large version of Layard's plan of the Northwest palace showing sculptures still in situ in early 2015

esp:image.esp:caption: Image 5: Layard's plan of his excavations at the Northwest Palace , marked in black and grey to indicate where complete or partial sculptures were still in situ before the destruction of the palace in early 2015 . (Rooms A, J, K, M, O, R, U, V, W, X, Y AA, BB did not contain figural bas-reliefs.) View large image.

dl.dd: Iraq War; Nimrud remains safe from post-war looting
ISIS invades northern Iraq, including Nineveh province in which Nimrud is situated
ISIS releases a propaganda video which shows the destruction of Northwest Palace; the status of the rest of the site is currently unknown
